summary:
I am (PhD, Royal Holloway University of London, 2019) a scholar of International Relations and critical security studies who works primarily on the Middle East. I am passionate about the international history of the Middle East during the Cold War, particularly studied through the lens of archival research and interviews with prominent diplomats and intelligence elites. 

My research has been published in leading academic journals such as Intelligence and National Security, Studies in Conflict & Terrorism, Oral History Review, and Cold War History among others. My academic publications also includes three book chapters in prestigious edited volumes among them one in genocide denial in the 21st century and one in Transitional Justice.

Currently, I am working in policy-oriented environment creating synergies between cutting-edge (academic) research and policy advice. I have authored six peer reviewed policy reports as an expert guest writer, providing policy advice to decision-makers. I strongly believe in knowledge transfer. I published (in Hebrew and English) short essays on current affairs and published more than 27 op-eds. My work appeared in Newsweek, The Conversation, The Jerusalem Post, Haaretz, The National Interest, Times of Israel, Mekomit, and Globes News.

I am a regular contributor to national and international media outreach. I have been invited to provide commentary to The Washington Post, The Jewish Insider, and The Media Line, TRT STRAIT TALK and Gloves News. I was also an invited speaker to international podcasts such as 'Secerts & Spies'. For invitations, please send me a DM via LinkedIn or Twitter.

My current research interests include:

- Israel's foreign policy and political history
- Israel-Turkey relations (all periods)
- Israel-Iran relations (all periods)
- Israel-German relations (all periods)
- Terrorism and counter-terrorism during the Cold War
- Israel's Intelligence and national security
- Critical security studies/Securitisation theory 
- Emotional diplomacy
- Elite Interviews and qualitative research 
- Jewish and Armenian transnationalism
- Nagorno-Karabakh conflict 
- Holocaust memory in the global age

My forthcoming book (Edinburgh University Press, Islamic & Middle Eastern Studies series) offers a critical re-examination of Israel’s relationship with Turkey in the last decade of the Cold War.

Twitter: @EldadBenAharon
ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0039-9827

treasury_media:
[{'url': None, 'title': 'Eldad Ben Aharon (2023) Methodological and epistemological reflections on elite interviews and the study of Israel’s intelligence history: interview with Efraim Halevy, Intelligence and National Security, 38:1, 111-127, DOI: Eldad Ben Aharon (2023) Methodological and epistemological reflections on elite interviews and the study of Israel’s intelligence history: interview with Efraim Halevy, Intelligence and National Security, 38:1, 111-127, DOI: 10.1080/02684527.2022.2095600', 'description': '10.1080/02684527.2022.2095600

In recent years, the literature on elite interviews has been receiving growing attention from scholars across diverse fields, especially those of intelligence and national security. However, this debate has mostly concentrated on the intelligence history of the ‘Five Eyes’ alliance, while neglecting the Middle East. Using Israel as a case study, this article explores the factors underpinning this lacuna. I argue that there is an acute need to apply a constructivist approach (as understood in international relations theory), with an emphasis on foreign policy analysis – i.e., a single-actor focus, which examines the experiences of individuals and their influence on decision-making processes. Elite interviews are the ideal methodological and epistemological means for this inquiry. Although they are not a silver bullet for the study of Israeli national security, elite interviews help not only to explore and situate Israel’s role in the field of global intelligence studies, but also to imbue intelligence scholarship with a sense of humanity, emotion and feeling. Crucially, this highlights the individual actors in a history that would otherwise be composed of merely impersonal processes and ‘top-down’ decision- making.', 'image': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C4D2DAQFqI99myUbYFA/profile-treasury-image-shrink_8192_8192/0/1673390682967?e=1692939600&v=beta&t=ggWoNGrYK59S2kqNFSWt7OvUpqOEF2WcGBKRjZk8xCk'}, {'url': None, 'title': 'Lapid must proceed with caution with Hezbollah - opinion

', 'description': 'הפוליטיקה של האשמה הגרמנית אל מול הסבל היהודי/ישראלי מיצתה עצמה בשני העשורים האחרונים • לממשלת בנט יש כעת הזדמנות וסיבות כלכליות ותרבותיות לשפר את היחסים עם גרמניה והאיחוד האירופי.', 'image': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C4D2DAQEQ1vBnr_Fg6A/profile-treasury-image-shrink_8192_8192/0/1634389186178?e=1692939600&v=beta&t=Yu9PvEB9HN8G1BSLSvPaYuAQx5xVxGWSmryQqAusKFs'}, {'url': None, 'title': 'Supporting Denial: Israel’s Foreign Policy and the Armenian Genocide
', 'description': "
Tuesday, 2 November 2021 -\xa02:15pm\xa0to\xa04:00pm

Add to Calendar

Venue:\xa0

The MEC Board Room, The Kirdar Building, St. Antony's College

Speaker(s):\xa0

Eldad Ben Aharon\xa0(Groningen)\xa0

Chair:\xa0

Yaacov Yadgar (OSGA and DPIR)

Series:\xa0

Israel Studies Seminar

In a milestone vote in late 2019, both the US House of Representatives and Senate overturned more than forty years of precedent to pass a bill declaring that the killing of 1.5 million Armenians by the Ottoman Turks was, in fact, a genocide. Subsequently, on 24 April 2021, also US President Joe Biden has officially recognized the Armenian genocide.\xa0 These decisions reinforced the importance of the subject\xa0matter\xa0and which offers the opportunity to learn how the 1980s were a formative period for the campaign for international recognition of the Armenian genocide. In his talk, Dr. Ben Aharon will assess how from the 1980s onwards, the state of Israel found itself in the remarkable position of supporting denial of the Armenian genocide. His talk takes us behind the scenes of the Israeli foreign ministry in the 1980s to examine how these state actors strategically\xa0mobilised\xa0the memory of the Armenian genocide into International Relations where it has remained for the following forty years. Dr. Ben Aharon will explore how Israeli diplomats took advantage of the growing international prominence of the 1915 Armenian genocide to court Turkey in the late Cold War period, leading to the emergence of a unique relationship between Israel and Turkey. The importance of this relationship is underlined by the successful role Israel played in supporting Turkey’s attempts to undermine the campaign by the Armenian diaspora to secure international recognition of the 1915 genocide.\xa0

projects:
[{'title': 'Elite Oral History Project (2015-2018)', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}}, 'description': 'My project draws on "elite oral interviews", which is an American based approach to oral history. While the British tradition of oral history gives emphasis to the neglected voices of ordinary people and their life stories, the American approach highlights the voices of the elite. We can, therefore, include businessmen, decision makers, state officials, and diplomats as those who are generally regarded as elite. The oral testimony here recounts the professional experience of these elite, in a wide range of topics related to historical and contemporary affairs.     

Since 2013, as a Master student at the University of Amsterdam and subsequently during my doctoral research at Royal Holloway, University of London, I have conducted more than 60 oral interviews with prominent Israeli, Turkish, and American former diplomats and state officials. the data emerging from these interviews promises to cast new light on the critical research questions emerging from a range of topics, such Cold War history, Middle Eastern studies, intelligence history, and Israel's foreign policy. 

During this extensive field research, I have gained considerable experience and insights which has provided significant advances in my current and future research projects. One of the outputs of this project, which summaries some aspects of my field research, can be found in my forthcoming article entitled: "Doing Oral History with the Israeli Elite: History and Memory and the Question of Israel's Clandestine Diplomacy". This manuscript is scheduled to be published in Spring 2019 in the Oral History Review. This article focuses on how the oral history methodology can enlighten the history of intelligence and clandestine diplomacy, specifically, Israel's Clandestine Diplomacy. You can find excerpts and anecdotes from the oral histories discovered from this project in my previously published articles.
